title: Bourke Street (painting)
text:
Bourke Street is a <a href="1886%20in%20art">1886</a> painting by Australian artist <a href="Tom%20Roberts">Tom Roberts</a>. Roberts originally titled the work Allegro con brio. The painting depicts the western end of <a href="Bourke%20Street%2C%20Melbourne">Bourke Street</a>, one of the main thoroughfares in <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a> as seen from the <a href="Buckley%20%26amp%3B%20Nunn">Buckley & Nunn</a> drapery.
The work was painted a few months after Roberts' return to Australia in 1885, after he had spent four years in Europe . It was not displayed until 1890, and only five days beforehand, Roberts added three female figures to the lower left. Roberts was unable to find a buyer and handed the painting to fellow artist, <a href="Frederick%20McCubbin">Frederick McCubbin</a>. In 1920, McCubbin's widow sold the painting to the <a href="Commonwealth%20Parliamentary%20Library">Commonwealth Parliamentary Library</a> for 20 <a href="Guinea%20%28British%20coin%29">guineas</a>—forwarding the proceeds to Roberts, who was in London at the time.
